Topic.Title: $299 Prime Flesh

Message.Msg: $299 per year considering cheap for someone deliver your favorite food right in front of your door.

Message.Title: Theater of the absurd and other short stories
Message.Msg: Let's see -- analysts are ecstatic over AMZN's proposal to enter the grocery business. Some analysts have breathlessly proclaimed that this assures AMZN's revenue growth will continue via a 568B market! Of course minor details such as razor thin gross margins in the grocery business are merely inconvenient details. For stock valuation purposes what could be better than to use the grocery stores revenues and use upscale luxury market margins! You have to love Wall Street. I have a few ideas of my own for AMZN. Why not tap into the gasoline market and deliver gasoline to households so they do not have to drive around to find gas in the morning. AMZN will deliver the cheapest gasoline right to the car in the driveway or garage! While they are at it, why not deliver electric power to the customers from the utilities at wholesale prices instead of the utilities sending power over expensive power lines (with resultant power loss). Here is the best one of all - why not deliver every conceivable product or service that has ever been conceived of to every household and every business. After all they can do it cheaper than anyone else with their incredible distribution centers! For example, drinking water and coffee at your place of work provided by the AMZN juggernaut. Help me out fellas -- you guys can figure out a few more.

Topic.Title: $299 Prime Flesh

Message.Msg: It might be a short term marginal boost for them because of the few suckers that sign up for it but unless they are gauging prices this has another money losing business written all over it. I heard Guy from Fast Money say that while the valuation is crazy that margins are improving here. Not the case at all since Prime costs are hidden. The reality is margins have not been improving. At what point will the cartel start to tell it like it is?

Message.Title: Channel Advisor May Data for Amazon assures they miss revs for Q2
Message.Msg: Data is worse than even I had predicted as a bear. May SSS up only 25.8% for AMZN vs. year ago Q (lowest reported number ever for AMZN). This number essential tracks 3P volume (AMZN only true profit contributor). Add in the April data, and AMZN is on track for 3P growth in Q2 to be about 33% (down from 39% in Q1, and 58% in 2012 Q2). Crank this in with other data (1P retail for Apr/May, cloud growth + gas prices), and Q2 will miss on both revenue (should come in around $15.5B) and amazingly on the reduced expectation EPS. If they are able to continue to push days payable they should be able to about breakeven on Free Cash flow. Now all of the hype makes sense - hiding the underlying issues of the core business - Q2 results will not be pretty. Amazon will see selling pressure today based on this.

Message.Title: AMZN is turning into...Walmart...but without profit
Message.Msg: Walmart market cap - 250 billion, rev (2013 est) 470 billion, rev growth 23% (2012-13) Amazon market cap - 126 billion, rev (2013 est) 74.8 billion, rev growth 5% (2012-13) Amazon price based on Walmart cap to revenue ratio: $92 Premium for growth and being in the "tech" group $277-$92 = $185 This is not mention that Walmart has much more assets, paying dividend (2.50%), and has a very reasonable PE of 15 and is also a well known name. My prediction? Longs with have no where to hide if growth drop below 20%. It could very well be this year. They might have to re-classify this as an online-retail stock than it will be game over.

Topic.Title: Maybe this is starting to make some sense

Message.Msg: Exactly HH ... they always had the incredible growth which led investors/analysts to beleive that scale would pay off down the road (it always had for good companies didn't it?). The details of the business that was being built was ignored (cost of shipping relying on increasing gas costs, ASP declines making the cost of shipping a larger % of cost, FBA costs, new 1P biz + 3P driving SKU increases making cost of inventory much more expensive, etc, etc....). All of these factors have the business more expensive to run with size, rather than less. There is a reason why companies control growth - to build a sustainable profitable company .. not sure AMZN understood that. Now it may be too late. With growth in massive decline, their flexibility to increase margins is gone ... what is there to look forward to now?

Message.Title: "The Great False Stock Market Conjectures"..
Message.Msg: If a company was once a growth company, it must be always a growth company.. If a stock was loved by the street, it will be always loved by the street. A company was growing sales first and never made any money. One year, it suddenly turned profits. Wow. We should model the stock price based on the sales growth in the future. One day, it will "Wow" and turn profit. One year, it didn't happen. We were patient. Second year, it didn't happen, we were patient.. Third year, it didn't happen, we were patient. Are you patient forever just because of that one year?

Topic.Title: "The Great False Stock Market Conjectures"..

Message.Msg: It is the model real?

Topic.Title: JUST HERE FOR A TRADE, BUT AMZN SHORTS MIGHT WANT TO READ THE CHINA NEWS

Message.Msg: You're a complete moron. You imply the Chinese ecommerce market is 900 billion. Go check on China's GDP. Come back and apologize for your incredible stupidity. Geez.....

Topic.Title: JUST HERE FOR A TRADE, BUT AMZN SHORTS MIGHT WANT TO READ THE CHINA NEWS

Message.Msg: I hope you're making money because the Chinese e-commerce market is much smaller. Estimated at 1.5 trillion yuan or 250 billion in 2013. So revenue increase with 3% is just $8 billion. 10% will give 25 billion but how much cost will they have to spend to get into this market? Growth in this market is starting to drop as well now just under 30%. Just more hype to hide the fact that hey have been failing at making money.
